The Facility and the Regulated Substances Handled

The Progress Energy Carolinas, Inc. Mayo Electric Plant is a coal-fired, electric power generating facility located in Roxboro, North Carolina.  The Plant uses ammonia in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system to control nitrogen oxides (NOx) emissions.  The SCR system is designed to inject ammonia gas into the Plant flue gas and then pass the ammonia/flue gas mixture through a catalyst.  The catalyst causes a reaction that reduces NOx (pollutant) emissions in the flue gas, converting NOx into nitrogen gas and water.  The Mayo Plant stores the ammonia in two (2) 21,890 gallon anhydrous ammonia storage tanks.  The anhydrous ammonia in the storage tanks is liquefied under pressure.  The Plant uses administrative controls to limit the maximum volume of each tank to 18,600 gallons.  The Risk Management Plan (RMP) addresses the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia used in the SCR system.


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies and Programs

The Mayo Plant has established an Accidental Release Prevention program for the ammonia system that complies with the regulatory requirements of both OSHA (Process Safety Management, PSM, 29 CFR 1910.119) and EPA (Risk Management, RMP, 40 CFR 68).  In addition, for responding to emergencies the Plant has an Integrated Emergency Response Plan that complies with a whole host of regulatory programs, including OSHA Emergency Response Planning requirements (29 CFR 1910.120(q)).  These plans have been coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).


Accident History and Recent Changes to Improve Safety

Since the process is newly constructed, there is no accident history.  However, to ensure a safe process, a HAZOP was conducted.  Opportunities to improve process safety were identified and implemented, including equipping the system with interlocks and excess flow valves and establishing emergency shutdown procedures.  As well, the ammonia
storage tanks were located in a dike designed to contain 110% of the entire inventory of a single storage tank.
